newsitem.title: INDIA: India's BPCL borrows 8.0 bln rupees.
newsitem.headline: India's BPCL borrows 8.0 bln rupees.

text.p: India's state-run refiner Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL) raised domestic debt of about 8.0 billion rupees in the past three months in fiscal 1997/98 (April-March), a company official told Reuters on Friday.
"We have raised about 8.0 billion rupees from April till now," a BPCL official said. The company's total borrowings stood at about 13.0 billion, he said.
Indian oil companies have been borrowing from the market because of large unpaid dues from the government for subsidising petroleum product prices to the consumer.
Analysts estimate dues owed to BPCL at 13.0 billion rupees.
The BPCL official said the company's borrowings last year were at an interest rate of 14-15 percent per annum.
"This year it (interest rates) would be lower," he said.
The government is debating a possible hike in oil prices but a decision has been postponed because of opposition from left parties within the ruling United Front governemnt.
On Thursday, the United News of India (UNI) news agency quoted Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral as saying that subsidies on diesel and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) would be slashed.
UNI said Gujral in an interview to state-run television also ruled out any further hike in kerosene prices.
